quote: Every person is wanted, and no person is wanted much.
author: Emerson

quote: Gain not base gains; base gains are the same as losses.
author: Hesiod

quote: The boy called out 'Wolf, Wolf!' and the villagers came out to help him. A few days afterward he tried the same trick, and again they came to his help. Shortly after this a wolf actually came, but this time the villagers thought the boy was deceiving them again and nobody came to his help.
author: Aesop

quote: None love the messenger who brings bad news.
author: Sophocles

quote: No evil can happen to a good person, either in life or after death.
author: Socrates

quote: They who are of a calm and happy nature will hardly feel the pressure of age, but to they who are of an opposite disposition youth and age are equally a burden.
author: Plato

quote: Perhaps some day it will be pleasant to remember even this.
author: Virgil

quote: Each of us suffers their own hell.
author: Virgil

quote: Appetite comes with eating, says Angeston.
author: Rabelais"

quote: People fear death as children fear to go in the dark; and as that natural fear in children is increased with tales, so is the other.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: I think that cars today are almost the exact equivalent of the great Gothic cathedrals. I mean the supreme creation of an era conceived with passion by unknown artists, and consumed in image if not in usage by a whole population which appropriates them as a purely magical object.
author: Roland Barthes

quote: Man should possess an infinite appetite for life. It should be self-evident to him, all the time, that life is superb, glorious, endlessly rich, infinitely desirable. At present, because he is in a midway position between the brute and the truly human, he is always getting bored, depressed, weary of life. He has become so top-heavy with civilisation that he cannot contact the springs of pure vitality.
author: Colin Wilson

quote: Academical years ought by rights to give occupation to the whole mind. It is this time which, well or ill employed, affects a man's whole after-life
author: Goethe

quote: At this point I'm going to tell you something you might not want to hear. It really matters to do well in your classes, even the ones that are just memorization or blathering about literature, because you need to do well in your classes to get into a good university. And if you want to start a startup you should try to get into the best university you can, because that's where the best cofounders are. It's also where the best employees are. When Larry and Sergey started Google, they began by just hiring all the smartest people they knew out of Stanford, and this was a real advantage for them. The empirical evidence is clear on this. If you look at where the largest numbers of successful startups come from, it's pretty much the same as the list of the most selective universities. I don't think it's the prestigious names of these universities that cause more good startups to come out of them. Nor do I think it's because the quality of the teaching is better. What's driving this is simply the difficulty of getting in. You have to be pretty smart and determined to get into MIT or Cambridge, so if you do manage to get in, you'll find the other students include a lot of smart and determined people.
author: Paul Graham

quote: “It was shown in Section 2.1 that the real and the imaginary parts of an analytic function satisfy Laplace’s equation. This and the fact that the occurrence of Laplace’s equation in physics is ubiquitous constitute one of the main reasons for the usefulness of complex analysis in applications.
author: Fokas and Ablowitz

quote: “By virtue of having stood the test of time, traditional practices embody greater knowledge about what is necessary for individual and social well-being than could be acquired during the lifespan of a single individual or by any social reformer.
author: Edward Feser

quote: If water is not piled up deep enough, it won’t have the strength to bear up a big boat. Pour a cup of water into a hollow in the floor, and bits of trash will sail on it like boats. But set the cup there, and it will stick fast, for the water is too shallow and the boat too large. If wind is not piled up deep enough, it won’t have the strength to bear up great wings. Therefore when the Peng rises ninety thousand li, he must have the wind under him like that.
author: Description of Buoyance by Zhuangzi

quote: The next real literary 'rebels' in this country might well emerge as some weird bunch of 'anti-rebels,' born oglers who dare to back away from ironic watching, who have the childish gall to actually endorse single-entendre values. Who treat old untrendy human troubles and emotions in U.S. life with reverence and conviction. Who eschew self-consciousness and fatigue. These anti-rebels would be outdated, of course, before they even started. Too sincere. Clearly repressed. Backward, quaint, naive, anachronistic. Maybe that'll be the point, why they'll be the next real rebels. Real rebels, as far as I can see, risk things. Risk disapproval. The old postmodern insurgents risked the gasp and squeal: shock, disgust, outrage, censorship, accusations of socialism, anarchism, nihilism. The new rebels might be the ones willing to risk the yawn, the rolled eyes, the cool smile, the nudged ribs, the parody of gifted ironists, the 'How banal.' Accusations of sentimentality, melodrama. Credulity. Willingness to be suckered by a world of lurkers and starers who fear gaze and ridicule above imprisonment without law. Who knows.
author: David Foster Wallace

quote: This was never a list for or about role-playing or role-playing games; we're elves. Deal with it, or not. It's up to you.
author: The Elfinkind Digest Landing Page

quote: In the 1960s, when history and English majors were among the most popular on campus, America was a very different place. This was an America where most kids memorized reams of poetry in school, where one third of the country turned on their television to watch a live broadcast of *Richard III*, and where listening to speeches on American history was a standard Independence Day activity. … This was a world where the humanities mattered. So did humanities professors. They mattered in part, as traditionalists like to point out, because these professors were seen as the custodians of a cultural tradition to which most American intellectuals believed they were the heirs to. But they mattered for a more important reason—the reason intellectuals would care about that birthright in the first place. Americans once believed, *earnestly believed*, that by studying the words of Milton and Dante, or by examining the history of republican Rome or 16th century England, one could learn important, even eternal, truths about human nature and human polities. Art, literature, and history were a privileged source of insight into human affairs. In consequence, those well versed in history and the other humanistic disciplines had immense authority in the public eye. The man of vaulting ambition studied the humanities.
author: Tanner Greer
work: "THE FALL OF HISTORY AS A MAJOR–AND AS A PART OF THE HUMANITIES"

quote: Ornament becomes valuable when it is used to add beauty to common things, and to relieve the blankness of bare walls, floors, and ceilings.
author: W. Smith Williams (1863)

quote: I understand that travel in other nations is different from travel within the United States. Programs outside the United States can involve inconvenience and risk, including, but not limited to, forces of nature, geographic and climatic conditions, different hygienic standards, infrastructure problems (including road maintenance, transportation delays and accommodation conditions), civil unrest, vandalism, crime, political instability, and terrorism.
author: CIEE Study Abroad Contract

quote: On a final note, keep in mind that most people in the world will see you not as a political entity or an appendage of the Great Satan but as a guest to their country. Even if they vehemently disagree with your country's policies and practices, they will invariably honor your individuality and regard you with hospitality and respect. You'd never guess this by watching the evening news, of course, but travel allows you to experience the nuances of the world in a way that mass media never will.
author: Rolf Potts

quote: The project of understanding the world lies at the bottom of who we are. Until we have pursued that project all the way, it is not just that we do not yet fully know what the desire to understand is a desire for, we do not yet know who we really are.
author: Jonathan Lear

quote: It is the human genius for communication that makes languages work, not the inherent structure of a particular language, nor even its origins.
author: Humphrey Tonkin

quote: There is no longer any excuse why, even in the most elementary lessons — nay, I should say why more particularly in these elementary lessons— the dark and dreary passages of Greek and Latin, of French and German grammar, should not be brightened up by the electric light of Comparative Philology.
author: Max Müller

quote: The total amount of suffering per year in the natural world is beyond all decent contemplation. During the minute that it takes me to compose this sentence, thousands of animals are being eaten alive, many others are running for their lives, whimpering with fear, others are slowly being devoured from within by rasping parasites, thousands of all kinds are dying of starvation, thirst, and disease. It must be so. If there ever is a time of plenty, this very fact will automatically lead to an increase in the population until the natural state of starvation and misery is restored…. In a universe of electrons and selfish genes, blind physical forces and genetic replication, some people are going to get hurt, other people are going to get lucky, and you won’t find any rhyme or reason in it, nor any justice. The universe that we observe has precisely the properties we should expect if there is, at bottom, no design, no purpose, no evil, no good, nothing but pitiless indifference
author: Richard Dawkins

quote: From all your herds, a cup or two of mill / From all your granaries, a loaf of bread / In all your palace, only half a bed: / Can man use more? And do you own the rest?
author: Ancient Sanskrit postmodern

quote: The act of working and being productive in American culture is in itself an affirmation of an individual’s worth. Americans take pride in what they do, and if they have to put up with adverse conditions to achieve their goals, they take additional pride in overcoming them: “We had to work around the clock and order in pizza at three in the morning, but the proposal looked great and we got the contract.” Such a comment from a French employee might sound to co-workers like a flimsy rationalization for aiding and abetting one’s own exploitation.
author: Au Contraire! Figuring out the French

quote: Remember, the execution is fixed for the day after tomorrow, and that you have but one day to work in. And what of that? Is not a day divided into twenty-four hours, each hour into sixty minutes, and every minute sub-divided into sixty seconds? Now in 86,400 seconds very many things can be done.
author: Alexandre Dumas

quote: Hæc olim meminisse juvabit—It will be a joy to us to recall this, some day.
author: Virgil

quote: A man who is always asking 'Is what I do worth while?' and 'Am I the right person to do it?' will always be ineffective himself and a discouragement to others.
author: G.H. Hardy

quote: We all want progress. But progress means getting nearer to the place where you want to be. And if you have taken a wrong turning, then to go forward does not get you any nearer. If you are on the wrong road, progress means doing an about turn and walking back to the right road; and in that case the man who turns back soonest is the most progressive man.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: Sure, it's possible to learn everything on your own, but it takes a lot of discipline, and that's what these online coding schools are selling: Discipline.
author: SamuelKnoche
work: "The Best Educational Institution in the World" (LessWrong)

quote: Seen up close and honestly, I expect the future usually to look like most places: mundane, uninspiring, and morally ambiguous, with grand hopes and justifications often masking lives of quiet desperation. Of course, lives of quiet desperation can still be worth living.
author: Robin Hanson

quote: A maniacal sense of urgency is our operating principle.
author: Elon Musk

quote: …we are born and die totally dependent on others… the independence we think we experience in between is a myth.
author: The Book of Joy (pg. 127)

quote: In every wise word and deed Ulone Acts
author: Mark Rosenfelder
work: In the Land of Babblers (Chapter 34: Draladeca)

quote: ‘Gentlemen,’ he said, ‘—by which I mean, of course, latter adolescents who aspire to manhood—gentlemen, here is a truth: Enduring tedium over real time in a confined space is what real courage is. Such endurance is, as it happens, the distillate of what is, today, in this world neither I nor you have made, heroism. Heroism.’ He made a point of looking around, gauging people’s reaction. Nobody laughed; a few looked puzzled. I remember I was starting to have to go to the bathroom. In the classroom’s fluorescent lights, he cast no shadow on any side. ‘By which,’ he said, ‘I mean true heroism, not heroism as you might know it from films or the tales of childhood. You are now nearly at childhood’s end; you are ready for the truth’s weight, to bear it. The truth is that the heroism of your childhood entertainments was not true valor. It was theater. The grand gesture, the moment of choice, the mortal danger, the external foe, the climactic battle whose outcome resolves all—all designed to appear heroic, to excite and gratify an audience. An audience.’ He made a gesture I can’t describe: ‘Gentlemen, welcome to the world of reality—there is no audience. No one to applaud, to admire. No one to see you. Do you understand? Here is the truth—actual heroism receives no ovation, entertains no one. No one queues up to see it. No one is interested.’
author: David Foster Wallace

quote: “If you’re going to start a company, first make sure you have a network, domain expertise, experience in running things, some personal runway, and some proof that you can do things.”
author: [anonymous]

quote: “Self-belief is immensely powerful. The most successful people I know believe in themselves almost to the point of delusion.”
author: Sam Altman

quote: You think you know when you learn, are more sure when you can write, even more when you can teach, but certain when you can program.
author: Alan J. Perlis

quote: And also, admittedly, for esthetic value. One earns the right to add ‘extraneous’ details by first putting in the hard work of removing the actual extraneous details; only after the ground has been cleared—the ‘data-ink ratio’ maximized, the ‘chartjunk’ removed—can one see what is actually beautiful to add.
author: Gwern

quote: A final word: when we do not understand something, it does not look like there is anything to be understood at all - it just looks like random noise. Just because it looks like noise does not mean there is no hidden structure.
author: johnwentsworth
work: Book Review: Design Principles of Biological Circuits (LessWrong)

quote: To be a philosopher is not merely to have subtle thoughts, nor even to found a school, but so to love wisdom as to live according to its dictates, a life of simplicity, independence, magnanimity, and trust. It is to solve some of the problems of life, not only theoretically, but practically. The success of great scholars and thinkers is commonly a courtier-like success, not kingly, not manly.
author: Thoreau

quote: Yet not the less, in my case, did I think it worth my while to weave them, and instead of studying how to make it worth men's while to buy my baskets, I studied rather how to avoid the necessity of selling them. The life which men praise and regard as successful is but one kind. Why should we exaggerate any one kind at the expense of the others?
author: Thoreau

quote: The very simplicity and nakedness of man's life in the primitive ages imply this advantage, at least, that they left him still but a sojourner in nature. When he was refreshed with food and sleep, he contemplated his journey again. He dwelt, as it were, in a tent in this world, and was either threading the valleys, or crossing the plains, or climbing the mountain-tops.
author: Thoreau

quote: Why is the great number of hard-working, innocent men who till the land every day of the year that you may eat all its fruits, scorned, vilified, oppressed, robbed; and why is it that the useless and often very wicked man who lives only by their work, and who is rich only through their poverty, is on the contrary respected, courted, considered?
author: Voltaire

quote: Executed on Mount Krapack, the thirtieth day of the month of Janus, the year of the world according to Scaliger 5722 according to Riccioli 5956 according to Eusebius 6972 according to the Alphonsine Tables 8707 according to the Egyptians 370000 according to the Chaldeans 465102 according to the Brahmins 780000 according to the philosophers infinity
author: Voltaire

quote: I believe in aristocracy, though — if that is the right word, and if a democrat may use it. Not an aristocracy of power, based upon rank and influence, but an aristocracy of the sensitive, the considerate and the plucky. Its members are to be found in all nations and classes, and all through the ages, and there is a secret understanding between them when they meet. They represent the true human tradition, the one permanent victory of our queer race over cruelty and chaos. Thousands of them perish in obscurity, a few are great names. They are sensitive for others as well as for themselves, they are considerate without being fussy, their pluck is not swankiness but the power to endure, and they can take a joke.
author: E.M.Forster
work: "What I Believe" - Two Cheers for Democracy

quote: It is like swimming. If you can’t swim, you won’t be having any fun at all. Swimming sucks if all you do is float (or even sink) and fight the water. But boy, if you figure out the technique and glide through the water, it is incredible. But you don’t learn swimming by aiming for ease and fun. You learn to swim by aiming to be fast and graceful
author: zwettelkasten.de

quote: Everyone holds his fortune in his own hand, like a sculptor the raw material he will fashion into a figure. But it's the same with that type of artistic activity as with all others: We are merely born with the capbaility to do it. The skill to mold the material into what we want must be learned and attentively cultivated.
author: Johanne Wolfgang von Goethe

quote: Many mathematical objects can be understood better by breaking them into constituent parts, or finding some properties of them that are universal, not caused by the way we choose to represent them.
author: Ian Goodfellow

quote: I want to learn more and more to see as beautiful what is necessary in things; then I shall be one of those who make things beautiful. Amor fati: let that be my love henceforth! I do not want to wage war against what is ugly. I do not want to accuse; I do not even want to accuse those who accuse. Looking away shall be my only negation. And all in all and on the whole: someday I wish to be only a Yes-sayer.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote:
He who cannot draw on three thousand years of history is living from hand to mouth, Goethe
So thoroughly and sincerely are we compelled to live
author: reverencing our life
work: and denying the possibility of change. This is the only way
column4: we say; but there are as many ways as there can be drawn radii from one centre."

quote: (2024_03_27 - from mandy) got any thoughts on 'so bad it's good' stuff? (games, movies, music, etc)* --- (Emma Essex): i don't really subscribe to the idea, i think mainly because they rely heavily on a shared idea of bad/good/etc, which most of the time i don't share. a lot of 'so bad it's good' also tends to focus on work made under strenuous condition or by people that haven't mastered their craft, and i think in those cases it's a lot better to admire that the thing exists the way it does. amateur charm and enjoyable jank tend to be a much healthier outlook on that, since they are so much more realistic - somebody being new to a form of art is normal, and things not reaching their full potential for any number of reasons is normal. from those normals, an unintended layer of enjoyment is created; not because it's bad, but usually because it's surprising. if something is 'so bad it's good,' it was never bad to you.*
author: Emma Essex via Slowchat (March 2024)

quote: Excellence is… Caring more than others think wise. Risking more than others think safe. Dreaming more than others think practical. Expecting more than others think possible
author: Tulsa Boy Scouts

quote: Learn, accept and move on.
One doesn't need to know the answers, only the process of finding them.
In times like the present, men should utter nothing for which they would not willingly be responsible through time and in eternity.
author: Abraham Lincoln
work: Second State of the Union Address (1862)

quote: The question of whether computers can think is like the question of whether submarines can swim.
author: Edsger W. Dijkstra

quote: There are two ways of constructing a software design. One way is to make it so simple that there are obviously no deficiencies. And the other way is to make it so complicated that there are no obvious deficiencies.
author: C.A.R. Hoare

quote: When I want to read something nice I sit down and write it.
author: Mark Twain

quote: All physicists and a good many quite respectable mathematicians are contemptuous about proof.
author: G.H. Hardy

quote: The object of mathematical rigour is to sanction and legitimize the conquests of intuition, and there was never any other object for it.
author: J. Hadamard

quote: You can't replace reading with other sources of information like videos, because you need to read in order to write well, and you need to write in order to think well.
author: Paul Graham via Twitter

quote: Pursue pleasure, and you will find pain. Pursue pain, and you will find pleasure.
author: Socrates

quote: If you hear a voice within you say ‘you cannot paint,’ then by all means paint and that voice will be silenced.
author: Vincent Van Gogh

quote: The quest for excellence is a lifelong process.
There, but for the grace of God, go I.
author: John Bradford

quote: This is the sort of nonsense up for which I will not put.
I admire dedication, but I admire blind obsession even more.
author: James Robinson Carter

quote: L'univers continuera d'exister même sans humains. Alors le fait que des machines prennent le contrôle, ça m'importe peu
author: Slangster

quote: Ne pleure pas, Alfred! J'ai besoin de tout mon courage pour mourir à vingt ans!
author: Évariste Galois

quote: Anybody can learn to draw, it just comes easier if youve been autistically drawn to it from a young age lol
author: Jules

quote: We exist mainly for each other. That's hard to realize when you're young because everything is given to you. You don't give anything to others.
Every artist teaches themselves their art.
A disaster is just an adventure looked at up close.
The more you do, the less you have to say.
Better to be an interesting failure than mediocre.
Any day I will take a real failure over an imagined success.
Mastery is running out of mistakes to make.
Any day when you don't fall flat on your face is a day wasted.
All good work needs only two ingredients: passion and time.
It's amazing how much better life becomes when you stop caring about things that don't matter.
The path to excellence is often simple, but it is never easy.
“Try to create at least as much as you consume.”
So goes the morning, so goes the day.
The fact that vegetables exist shows that nature cares for our well-being.

Basically all 21st century jobs are nothing more than information processing. This can all be automated.”
Better to pursue a stupid idea relentlessly than to never pursue any idea at all."
The categories were made for man, not man for the categories.
author: Scott Alexander

quote: “Emacs cures anxiety. Emacs cured my autism!”
author: Interview with an Emacs Enthusiast in 2023 [Colorized] (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=urcL86UpqZc&ab_channel=Programmersarealsohuman)

quote: Remember: it is not given to man to take his goods with him. No one goes away and then comes back.
author: The Song of the Harper (Stanza 10)

quote: Truth is great and its effectiveness endures.
author: The Maxims of Ptahhotpe (11)

quote: One who is serious all day will never have a good time, while one who is frivolous all day will never establish a household.
author: The Maxims of Ptahhotpe (25)

quote: Be cheerful while you are alive.
author: The maxims of Ptahhotpe (34)

quote: The mountain rests on the earth: the image of splitting apart. Thus those above can insure their position only by giving generously to those below.
author: I Ching -- Bk. I -- ch. 25 -- Po / Splitting apart

quote: Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived.
author: Job 3:3

quote: My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, and are spent without hope.
author: Job 7:6

quote: Before honor is humility.
author: Proverbs 15:33

quote: Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity. What profit hath a man of all his labor which he taketh under the sun? One generation passeth away, and another gener- ation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever. The sun also ariseth.
author: Ecclesiastes: 1:2-5

quote: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shall come after.
author: Ecclesiastes 1:11

quote: Hatred stirreth up strifes: but love covereth all sins.
author: Proverbs 10:12

quote: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring forth.
author: Proverbs 27:1

quote: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
author: Proverbs 27:17

quote: To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven. A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted; A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up; A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance; A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing; A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away; A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to speak; A time to love, and a time to hate; a time of war, and a time of peace.
author: Ecclesiastes 3:1-8

quote: Our time is a very shadow that passeth away.
author: Wisdom 2:5

quote: Winnow not with every wind, and go not into every way
author: Ecclesiasticus 5:9

quote: Let thy life be sincere.
author: Ecclesiasticus 5:11

quote: Swear not at all; neither by heaven; for it is God’s throne: Nor by the earth; for it is his footstool.
author: Matthew 5:34-35

quote: His countenance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow.
author: Matthew 28:3

quote: Knowledge puffs up while charity edifies.
author: 1 Corinthians 8:1

quote: He knew the things that were and the things that would be and the things that had been before.
author: Iliad -- I -- l. 70

quote: Men flourish only for a moment.
author: Odyssey -- XIX -- l. 328

quote: Those who harm others harm themselves, and the evil plan is most harmful to the planner.
author: Hesiod

quote: The dawn speeds a person on their journey, and speeds them too in their work.
author: Hesiod

quote: To produce things and to rear them, To produce, but not to take possession of them, To act, but not to rely on one’s own ability, To lead them, but not to master them— This is called profound and secret virtue.
author: Tao te Ching -- 10

quote: The softest things in the world overcome the hardest things in the world. Non-being penetrates that in which there is no space. Through this I know the advantage of taking no action.
author: Tao Te Ching -- 43

quote: True words are not beautiful; beautiful words are not true.
author: Tao te Ching -- 81

quote: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
author: Aesop -- Juno and the Peacock

quote: If cattle and horses, or lions, had hands, or were able to draw with their feet and produce the works which men do, horses would draw the forms of gods like horses, and cattle like cattle, and they would make the gods’ bodies the same shape as their own.
author: Xenophanes -- Fragment 15

quote: Things that are done, it is needless to speak about . . . things that are past, it is needless to blame.
author: Confucius

quote: When we see someone of good character, imitate them; when you see someone of bad character, turn inwards and examine yourself.
author: Confucius

quote: The virtuous person makes the difficulty to be overcome their first business, and success only a sub- sequent consideration.
author: Confucius

quote: The scholar who cherishes comfort is not fit to be deemed a scholar.
author: Confucius

quote: The person who in the view of gain thinks of righteousness; who in the view of danger is prepared to give up their life; and who does not forget an old agreement however far back it extends—they may be reckoned complete.
author: Confucius

quote: The superior person is distressed by their want of ability.
author: Confucius

quote: What the superior man seeks is in himself. What the mean man seeks is in others.
author: Confucius

quote: All is flux, nothing stays still.
author: Heraclitus

quote: This world . . . ever was, and is, and shall be, ever- living Fire, in measures being kindled and in measures going out.
author: Heraclitus

quote: He who commands the sea commands everything.
author: Heraclitus

quote: He who learns must suffer. And even in our sleep pain that cannot forget falls drop by drop upon the heart, and in our own despair, against our will, comes wisdom to us by the awful grace of God.
author: Aeschylus

quote: They say that this lot is bitterest: to recognize the good but by necessity to be barred from it.
author: Pindar

quote: What is God? Everything
author: Pindar

quote: Decay is inherent in all component things! Work out your salvation with diligence.
author: Buddha

quote: Sleep, that masters all.
author: Sophocles

quote: Time heals everything.
author: Sophocles

quote: Today's today. Tomorrow, we might be gone down the drain of eternity.
author: Euripides

quote: Every person is like the company they keep.
author: Euripides

quote: If we insisted always on being serious, and never allowed ourselves a bit of fun and relaxation, we would go mad or become unstable without knowing it.
author: Herodotus

quote: Not snow, no, nor rain, nor heat, nor night kept them from accomplishing their appointed courses with all speed.
author: Herodotus

quote: Often when looking at a mass of things for sale, we say to ourselves, 'How many things we have no need of!'
Those who have the fewest wants are nearest to the gods.
author: Socrates

quote: By convention there is color, by convention sweetness, by convention bitterness, but in reality there are atoms and space.
author: Democritus

quote: A wise person should consider that health is the greatest of human blessings, and learn how by their own thought to derive benefit from their illnesses.
author: Hippocrates

quote: Life is short, the art long, opportunity fleeting, experiment treacherous, judgment difficult.
author: Hippocrates

quote: We are lovers of beauty without extravagance, and lovers of wisdom without unmanliness. Wealth to us is not mere material for vainglory but an op- portunity for achievement; and poverty we think it no disgrace to acknowledge but a real degradation to make no effort to overcome.
author: Thucydides

quote: Somewhere, what with all these clouds, and all this air, There must be a rare name, somewhere . . . How do you like 'Cloud-Cuckoo-Land'?
author: Aristophanes

quote: A person's homeland is wherever they propser.
author: Aristophanes

quote: Either death is a state of nothingness and utter unconsciousness, or, as some men say, there is a change and migration of the soul from this world to an- other. . . . If death is like this, I think we gain when we die; for eternity is then only a single night.
author: Plato

quote: The hour of departure has arrived, and we go our ways—-I to die, and you to live. Which is better God only knows.
author: Plato

quote: He who is of a calm and happy nature will hardly feel the pressure of age, but to him who is of an opposite disposition youth and age are equally a burden.
author: Plato

quote: The beginning is the most important part of the work.
author: Plato

quote: Astronomy compels the soul to look upwards and leads us from this world to another.
author: Plato

quote: Let early education be a sort of amusement; you will then be better able to find out the natural bent.
author: Plato

quote: No human thing is of serious importance.
author: Plato

quote: [When asked what was the proper time for sup- per:] If you are a rich man, whenever you please; and if you are a poor man, whenever you can
author: Diogenes

quote: Hope is a waking dream.
author: Aristotle
work: From Diogenes Laertius -- Lives of Eminent Philosophers -- V.18

quote: What is a friend? A single soul dwelling in two bodies.
author: Aristotle

quote: Time crumbles things; everything grows old under the power of Time and is forgotten through the lapse of Time.
author: Aristotle

quote: The least initial deviation from the truth is multiplied later a thousandfold.
author: Aristotle

quote: Everyone by nature desires to know.
author: Aristotle
work: Metaphysics Bk. I ch. I l. i

quote: The actuality of thought is life.
author: Aristotle

quote: The things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them.
author: Aristotle

quote: It is possible to fail in many ways . . . while to succeed is possible only in one way (for which reason also one is easy and the other difficult—to miss the mark easy, to hit it difficult).
author: Aristotle

quote: Man is by nature a political animal.
author: Aristotle

quote: Well begun is half done.
author: Aristotle

quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
author: Politics

quote: Evil draws people together.
author: Aristotle

quote: Misfortune shows those who your true friends are.
author: Aristotle

quote: Every advantage in the past is judged in the light of the final issue.
author: Demosthenes

quote: When Heaven is about to confer a great office on any man, it first exercises his mind with suffer- ing, and his sinews and bones with toil.
author: Mecius

quote: I do not know whether I was then a man dream- ing I was a butterfly, or whether I am now a butter- fly dreaming I am a man.
author: Zhuang Zi

quote: The best victory is when the opponent surren- ders of its own accord before there are any actual hostilities. . . . It is best to win without fighting.
author: Sun Tzu

quote: We live, not as we wish to, but as we can.
author: Menander

quote: That is living, not to live unto onseself alone.
author: Menander

quote: Death is nothing to us, since when we are, death has not come, and when death has come, we are not.
author: Epicurus

quote: Time is the most valuable thing a person can spend.
author: Theophrastus

quote: [When asked late in life why he was studying geometry:] If I should not be learning now, when should I be?
author: Lacydes

quote: There are times when it is undoubtedly better to incur loss than to make gain.
author: Plautus

quote: No person is wise enough by themselves.
author: Plautus

quote: If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst forth at once in the sky, that would be like the splendor of the Mighty One.
author: Bhagavad Gita

quote: A farm is like a person—however great the income, if there is profit only a little is left.
author: Cato the Elder

quote: I would much rather have men ask why I have no statue, than why I have one.
author: Cato the Elder

quote: Nothing is so difficult that it can't be found by seeking.
author: Terence

quote: While there's life, there's hope.
author: Terence

quote: There is nothing so easy that it doesn't become difficult when you do it reluctantly.
author: Terence

quote: Not all who own a harp are harpers.
author: Varro

quote: Those who aim at great deeds must also suffer greatly.
author: Marcus Licinius Crassus

quote: History is the witness that testifies to the passing of time; it illumines reality, vitalizes memory, provides guidance in daily life, and brings us tidings of antiquity.
author: Cicero

quote: There is nothing so ridiculous that some philosopher hasn't said it.
author: Cicero

quote: Life is one long struggle in the dark.
author: Lucretius

quote: The best day ... is the first to flee.
author: Virgil

quote: Each of us bears his own hell.
author: Virgil

quote: Death twitches my ear. 'Live' he says; 'I am coming.'"
author: Virgil

quote: Why is it, Maecenas, that no one living is content with the lot that either their choice has given them, or chance has thrown in their way, but each has praise for those who follow other paths?
author: Horace

quote: We rarely find anyone who can say they have lived a happy life, and who, content with their life, can retire from the world like a satisfied guest.
author: Horace

quote: No ascent is too steep for mortals. Heaven itself we seek in our folly.
author: Horace

quote: It is sweet to let the mind unbend sometimes.
author: Horace

quote: To do two things at once is to do neither.
author: Publius

quote: Fortune is not satisfied with dealing only one disaster.
author: Publius

quote: Anyone can hold the helm when the sea is calm.
author: Publius

quote: Treat your friend as if he might become an enemy.
author: Publius

quote: Every day should be passed as if it were to be our last.
author: Publius

quote: No one knows what they can do until they try.
author: Publius

quote: It takes a long time to bring excellence to maturity.
author: Publius

quote: Everything is worth what its purchaser will pay for it.
author: Publius

quote: What when strength fails? Boldness will win praise. In great enterprises, it is enough to have had the determination.
author: Sextus Propertius

quote: To be loved, be lovable.
author: Ovid

quote: Nothing is stronger than habit.
author: Ovid

quote: You'll be safest in the middle.
author: Ovid

quote: Don't do unto your neighbor what you wouldn't have done to you. That is the whole Torah. The rest is commentary.
author: Hillel

quote: The best ideas are common property.
author: Seneca

quote: A great fortune is a great slavery.
author: Seneca
work: Moral Essays. To Polybius on Consolation

quote: A liar should have a good memory.
author: Quntilian

quote: Some good, some so-so-, and lots plain bad: that's how a book is made, my friend!
author: Martial

quote: Neither fear your death's day nor long for it.
author: Martial

quote: Perseverance is more prevailing than violence; and many things which cannot be overcome when they are together, yield themselves up when taken little by little.
author: Plutarch

quote: Medicine, to produce health, has to examine disease; and music, to create harmony, must investigate discord.
author: Plutarch

quote: Any one thing in the creation is sufficient to demonstrate a Providence to a humble and grateful mind.
author: Epictetus

quote: First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
author: Epictetus

quote: Remember that you ought to behave in life as you would at a banquet. As something is being passed around it comes to you; stretch out your hand, take a portion of it politely. It passes on; do not detain it. Or it has not come to you yet; do not project your desire to meet it, but wait until it comes in front of you. So act toward children, so toward a wife, so toward office, so toward wealth.
author: Epictetus

quote: Think of your forefathers and posterity.
author: Tacitus

quote: Each thing is of like form from everlasting and comes round again in its cycle.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: As for life, it is a battle and a sojourning in a strange land; but the fame that comes after is oblivion.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: The universe is change; our life is what our thoughts make it.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: Love the little trade which you have learned, and be content with it.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: All is ephemeral—fame and the famous as well.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: Nothing happens to anybody which he is not fit- ted by nature to bear.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: Look to the essence of a thing, whether it be a point of doctrine, of practice, or of interpretation.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: Whatever may befall you, it was preordained for you from everlasting.
author: Marcus Aurelius

quote: One principle must make the universe a single complex living creature, one from all.
author: Plotinus

quote: It is worse still to be ignorant of your ignorance.
author: Saint Jerome

quote: Whoever destroys a single life is as guilty as though he had destroyed the entire world; and whoever rescues a single life earns as much merit as though he had rescued the entire world.
author: Talmud --  Mishna -- Sanhedrin

quote: God will not take you to task for vain words in your oaths, but He will take you to task for what your hearts have amassed.
author: Quran -- Sura 2:225

quote: On the day of victory no one is tired.
Envy slays itself by its own arrows.
God is a sea of infinite substance.
author: Saint John of Damascus

quote: Against the disease of writing one must take special precautions, since it is a dangerous and contagious disease.
author: Peter Abelard

quote: Anticipate charity by preventing poverty; assist the reduced fellowman, either by a considerable gift, or a sum of money, or by teaching him a trade, or by putting him in the way of business, so that he may earn an honest livelihood, and not be forced to the dreadful alternative of holding out his hand for charity. This is the highest step and the summit of charity’s golden ladder.
author: Maimonides

quote: If in other sciences we should arrive at certainty without doubt and truth without error, we need to place the foundations of knowledge in mathematics.
author: Roger Bacon

quote: In silence man can most readily preserve his integrity.
author: Meister Eckhart

quote: A great civilization is not conquered from without until it has destroyed itself within. The essential causes of Rome’s decline lay in her people, her morals, her class struggle, her failing trade, her bureaucratic despotism, her stifling taxes, her consuming wars.
author: Will Durant

quote: In the middle of the journey of our life I came to myself within a dark wood where the straight way was lost.
author: Dante
work: The Divine Comedy -- Inferno -- Canto I.I

quote: Everyone confusedly conceives of a good in which the mind may be at rest, and desires it; so everyone strives to attain to it.
author: Dante
work: The Divine Comedy -- Purgatorio -- Canto XVII.127

quote: Don't be angry that you cannot make others as you wish them to be, since you can't even make yourself as you wish to be.
author: Thomas A Kempis

quote: Life well spent is long.
author: Leonardo da Vinci

quote: Iron rusts from disuse; stagnant water loses its purity and in cold weather becomes frozen; even so does inaction sap the vigor of the mind.
author: Leonardo da Vinci

quote: Man and the animals are merely a passage and channel for food, a tomb for other animals, a haven for the dead, giving life by the death of others, a coffer full of corruption.
author: Leonardo da Vinci
work: The Notebooks [1508-1518] -- vol. I -- ch. i

quote: Life well spent is long.
author: Leonardo da Vinci

quote: God is not willing to do everything, and thus take away our free will and that share of glory which belongs to us.
author: Niccolo Machiavelli

quote: There is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or more uncertain in its success, than to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things.
author: Niccolo Machiavelli

quote: Every experiment is like a weapon which must be used in its particular way—a spear to thrust, a club to strike. Experimenting requires someone who knows when to thrust and when to strike, each according to need and fashion.
author: Philippus Aureolus Paracelsus

quote: Those with patience may compass anything.
author: François Rabelais

quote: Thirty days hath November, April, June, and September, February hath twenty-eight alone, And all the rest have thirty-one
author: Richard Grafton

quote: Wherever your life ends, it is all there. The advantage of living is not measured by length, but by use; some men have lived long, and lived little; at- tend to it while you are in it. It lies in your will, not in the number of years, for you to have lived enough.
author: Michel de Montaigne

quote: There were never in the world two opinions alike, any more than two hairs or two grains. Their most universal quality is diversity.
author: Michel de Montaigne

quote: It [marriage] happens as with cages: the birds without despair to get in, and those within despair of getting out.
author: Michel de Montaigne

quote: There’s not the least thing can be said or done, but people will talk and find fault.
author: Miguel de Cervantes

quote: Absence, that common cure of love.
author: Miguel de Cervantes

quote: Journey over all the universe in a map, without the expense and fatigue of traveling, without suffering the inconveniences of heat, cold, hunger, and thirst.
author: Miguel de Cervantes -- Pt. II -- III -- 6

quote: Tomorrow will be a new day
author: Miguel de Cervantes

quote: Diligence is the mother of good fortune.
author: Miguel de Cervantes

quote: We are born into a world where alienation awaits us.
author: R.D. Laing

quote: Madness need not be all breakdown. It may also be breakthrough. It is potentially liberation and re- newal as well as enslavement and existential death.
author: R.D. Laing

quote: When television is bad, nothing is worse. I invite you to sit down in front of your television set when your station goes on the air . . . and keep your eyes glued to that set until the station signs off. I can as- sure you that you will observe a vast wasteland.
author: Newton N. Minow

quote: A mind content both crown and kingdom is
author: Robert Greene

quote: The monuments of wit survive the monuments of power.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Time, which is the author of authors.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: If someone will begin with certainties, they shall end in doubts; but if they will be content to begin with doubts they shall end in certainties.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: The human understanding is like a false mirror, which, receiving rays irregularly, distorts and discolors the nature of things by mingling its own nature with it.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Nature, to be commanded, must be obeyed.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Riches are a good handmaid, but the worst mistress.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Cato said the best way to keep good acts in memory was to refresh them with new.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: It was a high speech of Seneca (after the manner of the Stoics), that 'The good things which belong to prosperity are to be wished, but the good things that belong to adversity are to be admired.'
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Prosperity is the blessing of the Old Testament; adversity is the blessing of the New.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: In charity there is no excess.
author: Francis Bacon
work: Essays. Of Goodness and Goodness of Nature

quote: Fortune is like the market, where many times, if you can stay a little, the price will fall.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Intermingle . . . jest with earnest.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: If a person look sharply and attentively, they shall see Fortune; for though she is blind, she is not invisible.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Harmony is pure love, for love is complete agreement.
author: Lope de Vega

quote: Unbidden guests are often welcomest when they are gone.
author: William Shakespeare
work: Henry VI -- Part 1 -- Act II -- Scene ii

quote: Delays have dangerous ends.
author: William Shakespeare
work: Henry VI -- Part 1 -- Act III -- Scene ii

quote: Adam was a Gardener.
author: William Shakespeare
work: Henry VI -- Part 2 -- Act IV -- Scene ii

quote: The summer hath his joys / And winter his delights; /Though love and all his pleasures are but toys, /They shorten tedious nights.
author: Thomas Campion

quote: Never love unless you can / Bear with all the faults of man.
author: Thomas Campion

quote: Now that they are called masters, they are ashamed again to become disciples.
author: Thomas Campanella

quote: My face in thine eye ; thine in mine appears / And true plain hearts do in the faces rest / here can we find two better hemispheres / Without sharp North, without declining West?
author: John Donne

quote: I am a little world made cunningly Of elements, and an angelic sprite
author: John Donne

quote: I observe the physician with the same diligence as he the disease
author: John Donne

quote: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main; if a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were, as well as if a manor of thy friends or of thine own were; any man’s death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind; and therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.
author: John Donne

quote: True happiness Consists not in the multitude of friends, But in the worth and choice.
author: Ben Jonson

quote: For a good poet’s made, as well as born.
author: Ben Jonson

quote: Every one that flatters thee Is no friend in misery. Words are easy, like the wind; Faithful friends are hard to find. Every man will be thy friend Whilst thou hast wherewith to spend; But if store of crowns be scant, No man will supply thy want.
author: Richard Barnfield

quote: O God! O God! that it were possible To undo things done; to call back yesterday! That Time could turn up his swift sandy glass, To untell the days, and to redeem these hours.
author: Thomas Heywood

quote: All my joys to this are folly,, Naught so sweet as melancholy.
author: Robert Burton

quote: [Desire is] a perpetual rack, or horsemill, accord-ing to Austin [Saint Augustine], still going round as in a ring.
author: Robert Burton

quote: One was never married, and that’s his hell; another is, and that’s his plague.
author: Robert Burton

quote: Seneca thinks the gods are well pleased when they see great people contending with adversity.
author: Robert Burton

quote: Virtue and riches seldom settle on one person.
author: Robert Burton

quote: Is not old wine wholesomest, old pippins tooth- somest, old wood burn brightest, old linen wash whitest? Old soldiers, sweethearts, are surest, and old lovers are soundest.
author: John Webster

quote: Such truth as opposeth no man’s profit nor pleasure is to all men welcome
author: Thomas Hobbes

quote: No man is born unto himself alone; Who lives unto himself, he lives to none.
author: Francis Quarles

quote: Be useful where thou livest.
author: George Herbert

quote: The lion is not so fierce as they paint him.
author: George Herbert

quote: It is not enough to have a good mind. The main thing is to use it well.
author: René Descartes

quote: cSale often has surprising emergent properties.
author: Sam Altman
work: What I Wish Someone Had Told Me

quote: Don’t worry so much.  Things in life are rarely as risky as they seem.  Most people are too risk-averse, and so most advice is biased too much towards conservative paths.
author: Sam Altmman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Youth is a really great thing.  Don’t waste it.  In fact, in your 20s, I think it’s ok to take a 'Give me financial discipline, but not just yet' attitude.  All the money in the world will never get back time that passed you by.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: THEODORE ROOSEVELT has gone into the fight for the Mayoralty with his acustomed heartiness. Fighting is fun for him, win or lose, and perhaps this characteristic of his makes him as many friends as anything else. He makes a lot of enemies too, but so does anybody who is fit to live.
author: The Sun -- October 26 1886

quote: Necessity hath no law. Feigned necessities, imaginary necessities . . . are the greatest cozenage that men can put upon the Providence of God, and make pretenses to break known rules by.
author: Oliver Cromwell

quote: I would have been glad to have lived under my woodside, and to have kept a flock of sheep, rather than to have undertaken this government.
author: Oliver Cromwell

quote: But whether it be dream or truth, to do well is what matters. If it be truth, for truth’s sake. If not, then to gain friends for the time when we awaken.
author: Pedro Calderón de la Barca
work: Life Is a Dream — Act III line 236

quote: I have discovered a truly marvellous demonstration [of this general theorem] which this margin is too narrow to contain.
author: Pierre de Fermat
work: Note on Fermat’s Last Theorem — c. 1637 in his copy of Claude Bachet's Diophanti Alexandrini Arithmeticorum

quote: Persecution is a bad and indirect way to plant religion.
author: Thomas Browne

quote: Life itself is but the shadow of death, and souls departed but the shadows of the living. All things fall under this name. The sun itself is but the dark simulacrum, and light but the shadow of God.
author: Thomas Browne

quote: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, Stol’n on his wing my three-and-twentieth year.
author: John Milton
work: On His Having Arrived at the Age of Twenty-Three — 1631

quote: In those vernal seasons of the year, when the air is calm and pleasant, it were an injury and sullenness against Nature not to go out, and see her riches, and partake in her rejoicing with heaven and earth.
author: John Milton

quote: A good book is the precious lifeblood of a master spirit, embalmed and treasured up on purpose to a life beyond life.
author: John Milton

quote: I cannot praise a fugitive and cloistered virtue, unexercised and unbreathed, that never sallies out and sees her adversary, but slinks out of the race, where that immortal garland is to be run for, not without dust and heat.
author: John Milton

quote: No man who knows aught, can be so stupid to deny that all men naturally were born free.
author: John Milton

quote: Yet I argue not Against Heav’n’s hand or will, nor bate one jot Of heart or hope; but still bear up, and steer Right onward.
author: John Milton
work: To Cyriack Skinner upon His Blindness — c. 1655

quote: They themselves ordained their Fall. The first sort by their own suggestion fell, Self-tempted, self-depraved: man falls deceived by the other first.
author: John Milton

quote: Spirits, when they please, Can either sex assume, or both.
author: John Milton

quote: Before their eyes in sudden view appear the secrets of the hoary deep, a dark illimitable ocean without bound, without dimension, where length, breadth, and height, and time and place are lost; where eldest night and chaos, ancestors of nature, hold eternal anarchy, amidst the noise of endless wars, and by confusion stand.
author: John Milton

quote: Youth is the time of getting, middle age of improving, and old age of spending.
author: Anne Bradstreet

quote: Philosophy triumphs easily over past evils and future evils; but present evils triumph over it.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: We are never so happy nor so unhappy as we imagine.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: To succeed in the world, we do everything we can to appear successful.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: Silence is the best tactic for him who distrusts himself.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: The true way to be deceived is to think oneself more clever than others.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: Absence diminishes mediocre passions and increases great ones, as the wind blows out candles and fans fire.
author: François Duc de La Rochefoucauld

quote: In necessariis unitas; in dubiis libertas; in omnibus caritas.
author: Richard Baxter

quote: Nothing is there to come, and nothing past, But an eternal now does always last.
author: Abraham Cowley

quote: We shall die alone.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: Self is hateful.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: What a chimera then is man! What a novelty! What a monster, what a chaos, what a contradiction, what a prodigy! Judge of all things, feeble earthworm, depository of truth, a sink of uncertainty and error, the glory and the shame of the universe.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: The inexorable boredom that is at the core of life.
author: Jacques Bénigne Bossuet

quote: When all is done, human life is, at the greatest and the best, but like a froward child, that must be played with and humored a little to keep it quiet till it falls asleep, and then the care is over.
author: Sir William Temple

quote: All excellent things are as difficult as they are rare.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: You never enjoy the world aright, till the sea itself floweth in your veins, till you are clothed with the heavens, and crowned with the stars: and perceive yourself to be the sole heir of the whole world.
author: Thomas Traherne

quote: The months and days are the travelers of eternity. The years that come and go are also voyagers. . . . I too for years past have been stirred by the sight of a solitary cloud drifting with the wind to ceaseless thoughts of roaming.
author: Matsuo Bashō
work: The Narrow Road to Oku (Oku no Hosomichi)

quote: Mankind, by the perverse depravity of their nature, esteem that which they have most desired as of no value the moment it is possessed, and torment themselves with fruitless wishes for that which is beyond their reach.
author: François de Salignac de la Mothe Fénelon

quote: Happy the man whose wish and care / A few paternal acres bound / Content to breathe his native air / In his own ground.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: The knowledge of the world is only to be acquired in the world, and not in a closet.
author: Philip Dormer Stanhope

quote: The secret of being a bore is to tell everything.
author: Voltaire

quote: It is better to risk saving a guilty person than to condemn an innocent one.
author: Voltaire

quote: Or where the Northern ocean, in vast whirls, Boils round the naked melancholy isles Of farthest Thulè, and th’ Atlantic surge Pours in among the stormy Hebrides.
author: James Thomson

quote: Do all the good you can, by all the means you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, at all the times you can, to all the people you can, as long as ever you can.
author: John Wesley

quote: Dost thou love life? Then do not squander time; for that’s the stuff life is made of.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Human felicity is produced not so much by great pieces of good fortune that seldom happen, as by little advantages that occur every day.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Avarice-- the spur of industry.
author: David Hume

quote: Money is the seed of money, and the first guinea is sometimes more difficult to acquire than the second million.
author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
work: Discourse upon the Origin and Foundation of the Inequality Among Mankind

quote: The various modes of worship, which prevailed in the Roman world, were all considered by the people, as equally true; by the philosopher, as equally false; and by the magistrate, as equally useful.
author: Edward Gibbon
work: Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire — Chapter 2

quote: What country before ever existed a century and a half without a rebellion? . . . The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants. It is its natural manure.
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote: Art is long, life short; judgment difficult, opportunity transient.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quote: A noble person attracts noble people, and knows how to hold on to them.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quote: We can’t form our children on our own concepts; we must take them and love them as God gives them to us.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quote: Do you wish to roam farther and farther? See! The Good lies so near. Only learn to seize good fortune, For good fortune’s always here.
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quote: It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy;—it is disposition alone. Seven years would be insufficient to make some people acquainted with each other, and seven days are more than enough for others.
author: Jane Austen

quote: Mathematics is the queen of the sciences.
author: Gauss

quote: Free trade, one of the greatest blessings which a government can confer on a people, is in almost every country unpopular.
author: Thomas Babington Macaulay
work: Essay on Mitford’s History of Greece

quote: How to succeed: pick the right thing to do (this is critical and usually ignored), focus, believe in yourself (especially when others tell you it’s not going to work), develop personal connections with people that will help you, learn to identify talented people, and work hard. It’s hard to identify what to work on because original thought is hard.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: On work: it’s difficult to do a great job on work you don’t care about. And it’s hard to be totally happy/fulfilled in life if you don’t like what you do for your work. Work very hard—a surprising number of people will be offended that you choose to work hard—but not so hard that the rest of your life passes you by. Aim to be the best in the world at whatever you do professionally. Even if you miss, you’ll probably end up in a pretty good place. Figure out your own productivity system—don’t waste time being unorganized, working at suboptimal times, etc. Don’t be afraid to take some career risks, especially early on. Most people pick their career fairly randomly—really think hard about what you like, what fields are going to be successful, and try to talk to people in those fields.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Talk to people more. Read more long content and less tweets. Watch less TV. Spend less time on the Internet.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Go out of your way to be around smart, interesting, ambitious people. Work for them and hire them (in fact, one of the most satisfying parts of work is forging deep relationships with really good people). Try to spend time with people who are either among the best in the world at what they do or extremely promising but totally unknown. It really is true that you become an average of the people you spend the most time with.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Have clear goals for yourself every day, every year, and every decade.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Don’t worry so much. Things in life are rarely as risky as they seem. Most people are too risk-averse, and so most advice is biased too much towards conservative paths.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Youth is a really great thing. Don’t waste it. In fact, in your 20s, I think it’s ok to take a “Give me financial discipline, but not just yet” attitude. All the money in the world will never get back time that passed you by.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Learn voraciously.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Remember how intensely you loved your boyfriend/girlfriend when you were a teenager? Love him/her that intensely now. Remember how excited and happy you got about stuff as a kid? Get that excited and happy now.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Forgive people.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Don’t chase status. Status without substance doesn’t work for long and is unfulfilling.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Most things are ok in moderation. Almost nothing is ok in extreme amounts.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Be grateful and keep problems in perspective. Don’t complain too much. Don’t hate other people’s success (but remember that some people will hate your success, and you have to learn to ignore it).
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Be a doer, not a talker.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Given enough time, it is possible to adjust to almost anything, good or bad. Humans are remarkable at this.
author: Sam Altman
work: The Days are Long but the Decades are Short

quote: Give me the clear blue sky over my head, and the green turf beneath my feet, a winding road before me, and a three hours’ march to dinner—and then to thinking! It is hard if I cannot start some game on these lone heaths.
author: William Hazlitt
work: Table Talk. On Going a Journey

quote: We never do anything well till we cease to think about the manner of doing it.
author: William Hazlitt

quote: But there’s nothing half so sweet in life As love’s young dream.
author: Thomas Moore

quote: There are seasons, in human affairs, of inward and outward revolution, when new depths seem to be broken up in the soul, when new wants are unfolded in multitudes, and a new and undefined good is thirsted for. These are periods when . . . to dare is the highest wisdom.
author: William Ellery Channing

quote: What is a communist? One who hath yearnings For equal division of unequal earnings.
author: Ebenezer Elliott
